abstractText: In this paper, both the unpolarized and the polarized ρ meson generalized parton distributions are investigated in the framework of the Nambu–Jona-Lasinio model using the proper time regularization scheme. The symmetry properties of ρ meson generalized parton distributions are checked. The three independent distribution functions in deep inelastic scattering, F1ðxÞ, b1ðxÞ, and g1ðxÞ, and the Sachs-like charge, magnetic, and quadruple form factorsGCðtÞ,GMðtÞ, andGQðtÞ, which are the first Mellin moments of unpolarized generalized parton distributions, are obtained. In addition, the u quark axial vector form factors F̃1ðtÞ and F̃2ðtÞ related to the axial currents from the polarized generalized parton distributions are studied. The impact parameter dependent parton distribution functions, which are the two-dimensional Fourier transform of generalized parton distributions are studied, too. The obtained ρ meson generalized parton distributions satisfy the required properties well.

ρmeson generalized parton distributions in the Nambu–Jona-Lasinio model
Jin-Li Zhang ,1,* Guang-Zhen Kang ,2,† and Jia-Lun Ping 1,‡ 1Department of Physics, Nanjing Normal University, Nanjing 210023, China 2School of Science, Yangzhou Polytechnic Institute, Yangzhou 225127, China
(Received 3 November 2021; accepted 26 April 2022; published 16 May 2022)
In this paper, both the unpolarized and the polarized ρ meson generalized parton distributions are investigated in the framework of the Nambu–Jona-Lasinio model using the proper time regularization scheme. The symmetry properties of ρ meson generalized parton distributions are checked. The three independent distribution functions in deep inelastic scattering, F1ðxÞ, b1ðxÞ, and g1ðxÞ, and the Sachs-like charge, magnetic, and quadruple form factorsGCðtÞ,GMðtÞ, andGQðtÞ, which are the first Mellin moments of unpolarized generalized parton distributions, are obtained. In addition, the u quark axial vector form factors F̃u1ðtÞ and F̃u2ðtÞ related to the axial currents from the polarized generalized parton distributions are studied. The impact parameter dependent parton distribution functions, which are the two-dimensional Fourier transform of generalized parton distributions are studied, too. The obtained ρ meson generalized parton distributions satisfy the required properties well.
DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevD.105.094015
I. INTRODUCTION
The understanding of hadron structure has improved greatly in recent years. However, there is still a long way to go. An important step is the derivation of the factorization theorems, which indicates the scattering amplitudes of hard exclusive processes are the convolution of perturbatively computable coefficient functions and generalized parton distributions (GPDs) [1–13], such as deeply virtual Compton scattering (DVCS) [5,14–17], deeply virtual meson production (DVMP) [18,19], and timelike Compton scattering (TCS) [20,21] processes. Quantum chromodynamics (QCD) factorization theorems have been demonstrated for DVCS and DVMP in Refs. [22–24]. GPDs are useful tools to shed light on the origin of nucleon spin and the three-dimensional structure of hadrons at partonic level; therefore, an entirely new picture of hadrons at quark and gluon degrees of freedom is emerging. The understanding of the internal structures and the dynamics of hadrons—the mechanical properties of angular momentum [2,25], pressure, and shear forces [26,27]—is promoted with the help of GPDs. GPDs will reduce to parton
distribution functions (PDFs) [28–32], form factors (FFs) [33–36], and parton distribution amplitudes (PDAs) [37–41] in certain limits. Similar to the PDFs obtained from inclusive deep inelastic scattering (DIS), GPDs are defined as the nondiagonal matrix elements of the same operators at a lightlike separation between the respective parton fields, which means they parametrize the quark, antiquark, and gluon correlation functions involving matrix elements between different hadron states. Due to the different momenta of the hadron states, GPDs depend not only on the longitudinal momentum fraction x but also on two other kinematic variables: the square of total momentum transfer t and the skewness parameter ξ. The impact parameter dependent PDFs [42,43] are defined as the two-dimensional Fourier transform of the momentum transfer Δ⊥ of GPDs in the transverse direction at zero skewness (ξ ¼ 0). Impact parameter dependent PDFs can be interpreted as the density of partons with longitudinal momentum fraction x and transverse impact parameter b⊥. In the theory of GPDs, the moments of x play an important role. For ρ meson, the first Mellin moments of the unpolarized GPDs are FFs associated with vector currents, the combination of these FFs related to the Sachs-like charge, magnetic, and quadruple FFs, and the second Mellin moments correspond to the gravitational form factors. In the forward limit t ¼ 0, GPDs reduce to the three DIS distribution functionsF1ðxÞ, b1ðxÞ, and g1ðxÞ. Furthermore, the moments of GPDs can provide other information of nucleon structure, such as the quark orbital angular momentum [44,45] and the neutron asymmetry [46]. GPDs of spin 1 hadrons have been studied in Refs. are calculated in Refs. [10–12]. In this work we study the ρ meson GPDs [47,55,56] in the Nambu–Jona-Lasinio (NJL) model [57–66]. NJL model has an effective Lagrangian of relativistic fermions interacting through local fermionfermion couplings, which can keep one of the most important fundamental symmetries of QCD, chiral symmetry, so it is widely used in the strong interacting systems. The NJL model is often taken as a good start for exploring physical phenomena where the more realistic frameworks cannot yet provide insights or predictions. Our results in this work can be interpreted as the boundary values for further evaluation. This article is organized as follows: In Sec. II, we introduce the NJL model, then give the definition and calculation of ρ meson GPDs in the NJL model. In Sec. III, we display the properties of ρ meson GPDs, such as, the symmetry, its forward limit, and the Mellin moments. A brief summary and outlook are given in Sec. IV.

sections.heading: II. NJL MODEL AND GPDs
sections.text: The ρmeson, as a spin-1 object, is usually considered as a qq̄ bound state. Spin-1 particles have more GPDs than the spin-1=2 ones. In the leading twist, both the quarks andgluons have nine helicity conserving GPDs and nine helicity flip (transversity) GPDs, which were introduced in Refs. [51,49] respectively. In this work, we will calculate the nine helicity conserving GPDs of the u quark in the NJL model.

sections.heading: A. NJL model
sections.text:
The NJL model is Poincaré covariant; it describes the dynamics of interacting systems of relativistic fermions. It is a purely fermionic theory—the gluon degrees of freedom have been integrated out. sections.heading: A. Symmetry properties
sections.text:
The unpolarized GPDs are neither even nor odd functions of x; the combinations,

Here, we suggest that the orbital angular momentum of partons maybe also important in making up the spin of the ρ meson. We have illustrated Fu1ðxÞ, bu1ðxÞ, and gu1ðxÞ in Figs. 12–14. Our results show that Fu1ðxÞ is not zero at x ¼ 0, which can also be seen from the GPDs diagrams of Hu1 . The reason may be that the gluon degrees of freedom have been frozen into effective pointlike interactions between quarks in the NJL model. We can see that Fu1ðxÞ is approximately symmetric with respect to x ∼ 1=2.

sections.heading: IV. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSION
sections.text:
In this work, we evaluate the unpolarized and polarized ρ meson generalized parton distributions in the framework of the Nambu–Jona-Lasinio model using proper time regularization. Based on the results, the properties of GPDs are checked, and the results show that the required properties of GPDs are satisfied very well. Besides the three independent distribution functions in deep inelastic scattering, Fu1ðxÞ, bu1ðxÞ and gu1ðxÞ, and the Sachs-like charge, magnetic, and quadruple form factors GCðtÞ, GMðtÞ and GQðtÞ, are presented. All the results in the present work are generally consistent with those of previous calculations. In the future, on one hand, we plan to discuss the gravitational form factors of the ρmeson, which contain the information on the spatial distributions of energy, spin, shear forces, and pressure inside the system [26]. The gravitational form factors are defined through the matrix elements of the symmetric energy-momentum tensor, which can be obtained from the second Mellin moments of GPDs. The sum rules between GPDs and energymomentum tensor form factors can be found in Refs. [81,82], which is an extension of our current research.
094015-12
On the other hand, we will study the transversity GPDs, or helicity flip GPDs of the ρ meson introduced in Ref. [8]. As we mentioned, spin-1 particles have nine helicity conserving GPDs and nine helicity flip or transversity ones. Transversity GPDs appear as scalar functions in the decomposition of off-forward quark-quark correlators with a parton helicity flip. The helicity non-flip GPDs are chiral even, while the helicity flip GPDs are chiral odd.
